Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: There are a group of atypical genetic elements in the budding yeast, S. cerevisiae that are known as "yeast prions" because they are transmitted as altered, stable conformations of proteins. This is similar to infectious agents that have been characterized in mammalian systems. Yeast prion studies have provided valuable information on protein folding, information about proteins that assist folding of other macromolecules (molecular chaperone function), and information about protein-based infectivity. This project examines the molecular mechanisms responsible for the prion conformational switch of Swi1p. This protein functions as a subunit of an evolutionarily conserved complex named SWI/SNF, whose function is to remodel chromatin, the fundamental unit of DNA and histone proteins that condenses to form chromosomes. As condensed chromatin represses gene expression, chromatin remodeling by SWI/SNF plays an important role in regulation of gene expression. A combined approach of biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology will be used to 1) examine the structural requirement of Swi1p for prion formation and transmission; 2) identify interaction partners and cellular factors essential for Swi1 prion propagation; and 3) elucidate the biological significance of the Swi1 prion. Results from this investigation will significantly add to the understanding of prion biology and the role of Swi1 prion in chromatin-remodeling and regulation of gene expression.
Broader Impact: In addition to the intellectual merit, this project will be a platform for training postdoctoral fellows and graduate students as future independent scientists. Summer undergraduate interns will also be recruited from universities/colleges in the Midwest area. Another major educational goal of this project is to establish a High School Science Club program to connect high school students who are underrepresented minorities in the Chicago area with the biological science community in the Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern University. This includes after-school programs and summer camps. Planned activities include science-based discussions, talks and demonstrations, and hands-on activities. This project will likely propel the disadvantaged youth in the Chicago area towards further science education and potentially to a science-oriented career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Prions are infectious proteins that are now found in many types of organisms across different biological kingdoms, from bacteria to human. Prions are altered and self-perpetuating conformations of otherwise normal host proteins. Although the term ‘prions’ was first used to describe the pathogen that causes the devastating disease in mammals known as prion disease, the prion concept has now been expanded to explain many important epigenetic phenomena. In the budding yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, more than a dozen of prion elements have been identified and shown to play important roles in regulating many aspects of biological processes, such as transcription and translation. Yeast prions are important model systems for studying prion biology.

In this NSF-sponsored research project, we used a yeast prion named [SWI+] as a platform to address some important questions regarding prion biology. [SWI+] was discovered in our laboratory and its protein determinant is Swi1, a global regulator of gene expression. Using a systematic deletion and mutagenesis approach, we analyzed the length requirement for a prion-domain that confers prion formation and transmission. We also identified some critical amino acid residues that are essential for prion propagation. We found that a small region consisting of the first 32-amino acid residues of Swi1 contain all necessary information for de novo formation and propagation of the prion conformation. Using a combined approach of genetic, cell biological, and biochemical analyses, we also investigated the interactions of [SWI+] with other prion elements, such as [PSI+], [PIN+], and several other aggregation-prone proteins, Mss11, Sap30, and Msn1. We also carried out genome-wide RNA-sequencing experiments to survey if there are significant changes in total gene expressions between [SWI+] and [swi-] (non-prion) cells, using an isogenic mutant strain of swi1-deletion as control. Surprisingly, we found that [SWI+]-mediated regulation in yeast is complex: it can complete abolish some Swi1-dependent phenotypes, such as multicellular features of invasive growth and pseudohyphal growth, but only mildly affect some other Swi1-dependent phenotypes, such as non-glucose carbohydrate usage. Our results indicate that prion-mediated multi-level regulation might be important for cell adaptation. Moreover, we also identified a group of novel cellular factors that can either suppress the [SWI+] phenotype or eliminate the prion from the yeast cells. Their

In addition to this intellectual merit, the broader impacts of this project include training and education of our next generation scientists. Besides postdoctoral fellows and PhD graduate students in Northwestern University, we also trained a number of undergraduate and high school students from the Chicago area. Many of them were under-representative or minority students. About six undergraduate students and four high school students participated in the project.
